issue.title: Serial Backend Issues on Windows
issue.body:
When installed on Windows, the serial backend fails to correctly communicate with some USB CDC Serial interfaces. Specifically the Closed Loop Design CDC library ([http://www.cld-llc.com/adi.html](http://www.cld-llc.com/adi.html)), running on a ADSP-SC589 Processor (ARM Core). 

Running with a normal terminal emulator (VS Code Serial Monitor), the ADSP-SC589 with USB CDC responds correctly when "PRINT" is issued.  However, when using iio_info, the commands are never received by the device, and it times out.   

Devices running the Maxim MAXUSB stack ([https://github.com/Analog-Devices-MSDK/msdk/tree/main/Libraries/MAXUSB](https://github.com/Analog-Devices-MSDK/msdk/tree/main/Libraries/MAXUSB)) as CDC respond correctly to libiio, including iio_info.

Libserialport version 0.1.1 was re-built from source using MS Visual Studio (VS 2022 v143, Windows SDK 10.0, x64 target) and replaced the libserialport-0.dll provided by the libiio installer.  With this rebuilt DLL, everything works as expected.

It is unclear why the provided DLL does not function with all devices.

comment.body:
>Maybe @mhennerich can try with Pluto or M2k, on Linux's CDC gadget driver to see if the problem is in libiio, or in your MCU CDC stacks somewhere, ... Michael? (I think they show up as ttyACM# ?)

Sure - works for me on both Linux and Windows

On the target start iiod in USB gadget serial: (since I had iiod already running - I started iiod on a different port)

```
root@analog:~# systemctl stop serial-getty@ttyGS0.service 

root@analog:~# iiod -s /dev/ttyGS0 -p 2222
Starting IIO Daemon version 0.24.8ab3029c
IPv6 support enabled
Attempting to start Avahi
ERROR: host analog
Avahi: Registered 'iiod on analog #2:2222' to ZeroConf server avahi 0.8
Avahi: Started.
Avahi: Service 'iiod on analog #2:2222' successfully established.
```

On my desktop Linux: 
```
michael@xxxxxxxxxxx:$ iio_info -u serial:/dev/ttyACM0,115200,8n1 | less
iio_info version: 0.25 (git tag:cfb6249c)
Libiio version: 0.25 (git tag: cfb6249) backends: local xml ip usb serial
IIO context created with serial backend.
Backend version: 0.24 (git tag: 8ab3029)
Backend description string: Linux analog 6.1.0-20981-gb4b289b97539-dirty #445 SMP Thu Oct 26 11:14:06 CEST 2023 aarch64
IIO context has 7 attributes:
hdl_system_id: t on [ng] git branch d t git d clean [2022-10-12 15:19:33] UTC
hw_carrier: Analog Devices, Inc. Jupiter SDR
unique_id: 10400030fc0b0012110018000c17a3a87f
local,kernel: 6.1.0-20981-gb4b289b97539-dirty
uri: serial:/dev/ttyACM0,115200,8n1n
serial,port: /dev/ttyACM0
serial,description: IIO-USB-CDC-ACM - 12345678
IIO context has 10 devices:
hwmon0: ltc2945
```


On my desktop Windows
 
```
C:\Users\xxxxxxxxxxx>iio_info -u serial:COM6,115200,8n1
Library version: 0.24 (git tag: c4498c2)
Compiled with backends: xml ip usb serial
IIO context created with serial backend.
Backend version: 0.24 (git tag: 8ab3029)
Backend description string: COM6: Generic Serial Console (COM6)
IIO context has 5 attributes:
hdl_system_id: t on [ng] git branch d t git d clean [2022-10-12 15:19:33] UTC
hw_carrier: Analog Devices, Inc. Jupiter SDR
unique_id: 10400030fc0b0012110018000c17a3a87f
local,kernel: 6.1.0-20981-gb4b289b97539-dirty
uri: serial:COM6,115200,8n1n
IIO context has 10 devices:
```

Note: iio_info -u serial:COM6 works equally well.

I was also running into:
ERROR: Unable to create local context: Inappropriate ioctl for device (25)

strace:
```
lstat64("/sys/class/tty/ttyGS0", {st_mode=S_IFLNK|0777, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
readlink("/sys/class/tty/ttyGS0", "../../devices/virtual/tty/ttyGS0", 4096) = 32
openat(AT_FDCWD, "/dev/ttyGS0", O_RDWR|O_NOCTTY|O_NONBLOCK|O_LARGEFILE) = 4
ioctl(4, TCGETS, {B9600 opost isig icanon echo ...}) = 0
ioctl(4, TIOCMGET, 0xff875974)          = -1 ENOTTY (Inappropriate ioctl for device)
close(4)                                = 0
write(2, "ERROR: Unable to create local co"..., 75ERROR: Unable to create local context: Inappropriate ioctl for device (25)
) = 75
close(3)                                = 0
exit_group(1)                           = ?
+++ exited with 1 +++
```

But that error was causes by getty running on ttyGS0.
After I stopped that service, iiod started normally.

issue.title: Serial Backend Issues on Windows
issue.body:
When installed on Windows, the serial backend fails to correctly communicate with some USB CDC Serial interfaces. Specifically the Closed Loop Design CDC library ([http://www.cld-llc.com/adi.html](http://www.cld-llc.com/adi.html)), running on a ADSP-SC589 Processor (ARM Core). 

Running with a normal terminal emulator (VS Code Serial Monitor), the ADSP-SC589 with USB CDC responds correctly when "PRINT" is issued.  However, when using iio_info, the commands are never received by the device, and it times out.   

Devices running the Maxim MAXUSB stack ([https://github.com/Analog-Devices-MSDK/msdk/tree/main/Libraries/MAXUSB](https://github.com/Analog-Devices-MSDK/msdk/tree/main/Libraries/MAXUSB)) as CDC respond correctly to libiio, including iio_info.

comment.body:
@BrentK-ADI : I have seen differences even with CDC-ACM having the "wrong" baud rate - I can't explain why, but if I rememeber properly - it did make a difference. On Windows, it's just : `serial:comm3,115200,8n1`

Maybe @mhennerich can try with Pluto or M2k, on Linux's CDC gadget driver to see if the problem is in libiio, or in your MCU CDC stacks somewhere, ... Michael? (I think they show up as ttyACM# ?)

issue.title: Cherry pick commits from libiio-v0 branch

comment.body: @SRaus OK. I think you could have merged, as everything that goes into `libiio-v0` now are just fixes. The problem with cherry-picking individual patches is that it may be a pain to switch `next_stable` to the future v1.0 release later if it diverges too much.

payload.description: A cross platform library for interfacing with local and remote Linux IIO devices

commits.message:
CI: Fix MinGW build

And print the content of C:\ghcup\ghc\ to make it easier to debug CI
errors in the future.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>
(cherry picked from commit aa8f9462d88c021ffefe41a44ffe953f80fd4e1c)
(cherry picked from commit cfb6249cc26f157055c325fa5ffbc4d7f34521fe)

CI/build_win.ps1: Fix cmake using the wrong python version

Added a flag for cmake which sets the python version to the one used by
the system (configured in azure-pipelines.yml).

Signed-off-by: Andreea Andrisan <Andreea.Andrisan@analog.com>
(cherry picked from commit 34a2aef458898c7db5bee1aaa6e1ef8e86aeebfa)

CI:publish_deps.ps1: fix MinGW build

Install 9.2.8 version of ghc because it's not supported anymore
on windows-2022 image from azure.

Signed-off-by: Andreea Andrisan <Andreea.Andrisan@analog.com>
(cherry picked from commit 0d8a69aaf2f064cafaa9a962308f679f9b8fa982)

issue.title: Cherry pick commits from libiio-v0 branch

comment.body:
> Why not just merge `libiio-v0` into `next_stable`?

Hi Paul.
The 'next_stable' and 'libiio-v0' branches started to diverge. Previous commits in 'next_stable' where added also with cherry-picks from other branches. Since we are so close to Kuiper release, we just don't want to do mass cherry-picking or rebase, but to add only the strictly necessary commits. 
In this case, there are only CI changes, so they won't broke anything. but in general, we are trying to follow the above described flow.

issue.title: Cherry pick commits from libiio-v0 branch

pull_request.title: Cherry pick commits from libiio-v0 branch

repo.name: libiio
repo.description: A cross platform library for interfacing with local and remote Linux IIO devices

payload.description: A cross platform library for interfacing with local and remote Linux IIO devices

commits.message:
sort: Update iio_channel_compare()

This function is not used anywhere right now, so it can be updated
without side effects.

The previous algorithm is better, but was eventually left unused as
it would change the ordering of the channels within an IIO context,
which caused communication problems between libiio and a remote IIOD.

Update iio_channel_compare() to mirror the algorithm used in
reorder_channels() in context.c.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

sort: Add functions iio_sort_{devices,channels}

These two functions can be used to sort the array of devices of a
context, and the array of channels of a device, respectively.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Order devices with iio_sort_devices()

Use the new function iio_sort_devices() instead of calling qsort()
manually.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

context: Order channels with iio_sort_channels()

Use the new iio_sort_channels() function instead of using a custom
algorithm.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

sort: Make iio_{channel,device}_compare() static

These functions can be "static" now, as they are never called outside
sort.c.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

context: Fix prototype of iio_xml_print_and_sanitized_param()

The "param" function argument should be a pointer to a const string.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

Add new iio_attr API

Instead of having a plethora of functions to address the various
attributes of iio_context, iio_channel and the three types of attributes
for iio_device, introduce a new "iio_attr" type with its own API.

A few API functions have been introduced:
- iio_attr_read_raw(), and the generic iio_attr_read() which will
  fall back to iio_attr_read_bool(), iio_attr_read_longlong(), or
  iio_attr_read_double().

- iio_attr_write_raw(), and the generic iio_attr_write() which will
  fall back to iio_attr_write_string(), iio_attr_write_bool(),
  iio_attr_write_longlong() or iio_attr_write_double().

- The name of the attribute can be obtained with iio_attr_get_name().

- The filename of the attribute can be obtained with
  iio_attr_get_filename(). Generally different only for channel
  attributes.

- For context attributes where the value is always known,
  iio_attr_get_static_value() can be used to get a "const char *"
  pointer to the value. For every other argument type, it will return
  NULL.

This commit adds a lot of functions, but in the long run it will result
in a much simpler API.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

buffer: Add new iio_attr API functions

Add functions iio_buffer_get_attrs_count(), iio_buffer_get_attr(), and
iio_buffer_find_attr().

These functions can be used to retrieve buffer attributes from a
iio_buffer object.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

sort: Add function iio_sort_attrs()

This function can be used to sort the attributes found in an
iio_attr_list.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

Add API function iio_context_find_attr()

This function can be used to find a context attribute by name.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

dns-sd: Use the new attribute API functions

Avoid using iio_context_get_attr_value(), which will be removed soon.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

context: Update iio_context_get_attr() and switch to use iio_attr

Update the prototype of iio_context_get_attr() to return a pointer to a
"struct iio_attr", and update the code to use the new attribute list
internally.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Handle reading multi-buffer attributes

The attribute read callback did not support multi-buffer setups, unlike
the attribute write callback.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Avoid using old API to read attributes

The API functions iio_channel_attr_read_raw() and
iio_device_attr_read_raw() will soon disappear.

Use the corresponding backend functions instead.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Implement local_{read,write}_attr()

Implement the two backend functions local_read_attr() and
local_write_attr(), which will then allow the new "iio_attr" attributes
to work with the local backend.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Switch to new iio_attr API

Instead of creating the channel and device attributes the old way, use
the new iio_attr API and populate the iio_attr_list structures present
in the iio_device and iio_channel structures.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

local: Remove old attribute read/write backend ops

Those backend ops are deprecated in favour of the .read_attr() and
.write_attr() backend ops.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

xml: Switch to new iio_attr API

Instead of creating the channel and device attributes the old way, use
the new iio_attr API and populate the iio_attr_list structures present
in the iio_device and iio_channel structures.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

sort: Remove unused functions

Remove the following functions:
- iio_channel_attr_compare()
- iio_device_attr_compare()
- iio_buffer_attr_compare()
- iio_context_info_compare()

Which are not used anywhere anymore.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

iiod-client: Update to use new iio_attr API

Replace the iiod_client_attr_{read,write} functions with the new
iiod_client_{read,write}_attr ones. The former are now duds and will
simply return -ENOSYS. This is just temporary, until all the backends
that use iiod-client are updated to use the new functions.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

commits.message:
python: Update to new IIO attributes API

Use a single iio.Attr class to represent attributes, to follow the
latest developments of the Libiio v1.0 API.

This also simplifies a lot the code. The pyiio API itself almost did not
change; the only main differences are that buffer attributes are now
available from the iio.Buffer class, and there's now only a single
iio.Attr class instead of multiple ones.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

python: Update to new IIO attributes API

Use a single iio.Attr class to represent attributes, to follow the
latest developments of the Libiio v1.0 API.

This also simplifies a lot the code. The pyiio API itself almost did not
change; the only main differences are that buffer attributes are now
available from the iio.Buffer class, and there's now only a single
iio.Attr class instead of multiple ones.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

issue.title: buffer auto disables some time after calling iio_buffer_enable()
issue.body:
I have some a custom HDL core connected to the FPGA ad9361 core. I need to enable the DAC channel so that my samples get played out on the DAC. I do this by creating a bufffer, then creating a dummy block (which never gets used) and then calling iio_buffer_enable().

The problem is that after a while, about 30s the buffer auto disables itself. Is this a bug or feature?
I noticed that I have to create a block before calling iio_buffer_enable(), therefore I am creating this dummy block. Is there a cleaner way to just enable a DAC channel, maybe by writing directly to a register or so?

(I am using libiio 1.0 on both sides)

comment.body: Did your app set a 30-seconds timeout somewhere? That sounds like a strange value. Libiio typically uses a 1 second timeout value for the local backend, and a 5 seconds timeout value for the network and USB backends.

commits.message:
python: Update to new IIO attributes API

Use a single iio.Attr class to represent attributes, to follow the
latest developments of the Libiio v1.0 API.

This also simplifies a lot the code. The pyiio API itself almost did not
change; the only main differences are that buffer attributes are now
available from the iio.Buffer class, and there's now only a single
iio.Attr class instead of multiple ones.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

commits.message:
CI: Limit FreeBSD CI time to 30 minutes

A FreeBSD 12.3 CI build takes less than 10 minutes. However, FreeBSD
13.2 will currently hang somewhere, causing the CI to fail after a
timeout of 6 hours.

Since that's way too long, reduce the maximum CI time for FreeBSD to 30
minutes.

Signed-off-by: Paul Cercueil <paul@crapouillou.net>

issue.title: buffer auto disables some time after calling iio_buffer_enable()
issue.body:
I have some a custom HDL core connected to the FPGA ad9361 core. I need to enable the DAC channel so that my samples get played out on the DAC. I do this by creating a bufffer, then creating a dummy block (which never gets used) and then calling iio_buffer_enable().

The problem is that after a while, about 30s the buffer auto disables itself. Is this a bug or feature?
I noticed that I have to create a block before calling iio_buffer_enable(), therefore I am creating this dummy block. Is there a cleaner way to just enable a DAC channel, maybe by writing directly to a register or so?

(I am using libiio 1.0 on both sides)

comment.body:
I think it's realy like I described. I create a buffer, create a block, enable the buffer
and then after about 30s the buffer gets disabled. I noticed that the function `axi_dmac_terminate_all()` inside dma-axi-dmac.c gets called. It gets probably called via `libiio's iio_buffer_cancel()` or `iio_buffer_destroy()`

Since that's way too long, reduce the maximum CI time for FreeBSD to 30 minutes.
